Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Superficial Surgical Site Infection Rates Between Delayed Primary and Primary Wound Closure for Complicated Appendicitis

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were adults with gangrenous or ruptured appendicitis. They were randomised to either PC or DPC.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with gangrenous or ruptured appendicitis. A multicenter randomised controlled trial was conducted in six hospitals in Thailand.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either PC or DPC.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare SSI rates between delayed primary wound closure (DPC) and primary wound closure (PC).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of superficial SSI within 30 days, defined by the Center for Disease Control criteria.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using permuted blocks, and allocation was concealed in sealed opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to research assistants assessing subjective outcomes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 607 patients were randomised, with 303 to PC and 304 to DPC.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Modified intention-to-treat analysis included 300 in PC and 298 in DPC.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The SSI rate was 7.3% in PC and 10% in DPC, with a risk difference of −2.7% (95% CI −7.1% to 1.9%), not statistically significant.

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
